name: Breakdown of average total household expenditure
fact: The current method for recording  expenditure is introduced.  Transport spending is £88.00  (adjusted for inflation), the highest  of the 12 COICOP categories.
Expenditure on transport,  and restaurants and hotels,  reach their highest levels  for the period 2001-02 to  2013, once adjusted for inflation.
Housing (net), fuel and power  overtakes food and non-alcoholic  drinks as second-highest  expenditure category. Spending  in these categories is very similar  until 2009.
Spending on household goods and services  (furniture, appliances etc.) reaches its  highest level of £37.60, at 2013 prices.
Family Spending celebrates 50 years  of household expenditure surveys.  Total expenditure falls slightly, adjusted for inflation.
Expenditure on recreation  and culture exceeds spending  on food and non-alcoholic  drink for the first time since  current recording methods  began in 2001-02.
For the only time since current recording methods  began in 2001-2, average spending is lower than  the previous year without adjusting for inflation.
Household spending on clothing and footwear is at its  peak since 2001-02 at £24.30 (adjusted for inflation).
Inflation-adjusted expenditure on household  goods and services (furniture, appliances etc.) falls  its lowest over the period 2001-02 to 2013.
Total expenditure adjusted for inflation  reaches its lowest point in the series,  while spending on restaurants and hotels  falls for a 6th consecutive year.
Expenditure on  housing (net),  fuel and power  reaches its highest  level in the series since  current recording methods  began at £74.40.
